title: Diane Abbott appears to fall asleep during historic Brexit debate
text:
Diane Abbott appears to have nodded off next to Sir Kier Starmer

The ongoing debate over Brexit has left many in the UK exasperated and exhausted.

Not least Labour’s Diane Abbott, who appeared to nod off during today’s lengthy debate in the House of Commons.

The Shadow Home Secretary could be seen resting her eyes on the front benches while Sir Kier Starmer set out Labour’s opposition to Boris Johnson’s new deal.

By this point many Tories had left the room, including the PM who needs rebel Labour MPs to back him in a knife-edge vote later today.

As she went into the Commons, Ms Abbott tweeted: ‘Off to Parliament today to vote against Boris Johnson’s bad Brexit deal.

‘A bad deal for jobs and the economy. No Labour MP could be fooled by Boris surely?!’

But three hours in, it appeared she may have started to flag as many of the 650 MPs had their say on the subject.

Sadly the eyes of Twitter were upon her, with many people taking to social media to berate the timing of her alleged snooze.

Kieran_S tweeted: ‘Diane Abbott is asleep during this very important day.

‘I guess she couldn’t face having to work her first Saturday ever.

‘Not to worry, she makes more sense when she is asleep.’

Dylan Pemberton said: ‘Unbelievable. Utter disrespect for the voters.’

Alan Woodward questioned whether falling asleep at work was a sackable offence.

But a few came to her defence with Milk Media saying: ‘To be fair to Diane Abbot, I’d probably be asleep as well.’

Off to Parliament today to vote against Boris Johnson’s bad Brexit deal. A bad deal for jobs and the economy. No Labour MP could be fooled by Boris surely?! pic.twitter.com/Dz4qwHiCis — Diane Abbott (@HackneyAbbott) October 19, 2019

It seems Ms Abbott did manage to wake up as she left the chamber to attend the People’s Vote march around Parliament demanding a second referendum.

The House of Commons is sitting at a weekend for the first time in 37 years for a crunch vote on our exit from the EU on October 31.

The result of the vote is still too close to call after Mr Johnson’s former DUP allies announced they would reject it.

They have accused him of ‘selling out’ Northern Ireland by keeping them aligned to some EU trade rules in his desperate ‘do or die’ bid to leave.

Labour say the deal is bad for the economy and fails to protect workers’ rights and dilutes environmental standards.

Boris Johnson has been attempting to sell his new deal to the UK Parliament (Picture: Reuters)

Speaking next to Ms Abbott, Shadow Brexit Secretary Sir Kier Starmer said: ‘There’s been a lot of attention on how the deal operates in Northern Ireland, and rightly so, but that shouldn’t be allowed to mask the political project that is driving this deal.

‘So it’s clear what this deal does, it rips up our close trading relationship with the EU and the price will be paid in damage to our economy and in job losses.’

Mr Johnson agreed a new deal with EU officials on Thursday and has been on a charm offensive for the last 48 hours to woo the Tories he sacked last month as well as wavering Labour politicians.

As he opened today’s debate in the House of Commons he said: ‘The House will need no reminding that this is the second deal and the fourth vote, three-and-a-half years after the nation voted for Brexit.

‘And during those years friendships have been strained, families divided and the attention of this House consumed by a single issue that has at times felt incapable of resolution.

‘But I hope that this is the moment when we can finally achieve that resolution and reconcile the instincts that compete within us.’

Before the main vote, politicians will have their say on a series of amendments, including one by former Tory minister Sir Oliver Letwin.

He wants a delay to ensure that all the legislation is in place to stop the UK accidentally crashing out without a deal.

That would see the Benn Act enacted, which would force Mr Johnson to ask the EU for a three-month delay.
